bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 28, 1890

div1.p: Lazear writes that he wants to spend September in Germany to practice German, rather than returning to New York.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 28, 1890
div1.p:
Your letter with papers
came on Thursday. I have not had
time to read all the papers yet but
I will get them all read up
tomorrow I enjoy the “Times” very
much. It is an excellent paper.
It makes me feel homesick for
New York sometimes. I notice in
it that Johns Hopkins University is
to get $58000 a year from its B & C
stock. It does not say how the deal
was arranged. Perhaps you may
have heard something about it,

I have been sticking very close
to my work and I feel that I am
accomplishing a great deal. Every
moments work tells now; I have
every advantage in the way of instruction
specimens, & apparatus, I and I think
they best thing I can do is to put
every moment I have unto the work.
There is only three weeks more of it, and
I will then get a good rest.
I don't feel the need of rest at all
and my health is as good as
it could possibly be.

When I left home I thought it
would be better for me to return
by the first of September and get
some practical work in a Dispensary
for the month of September. But
I am beginning to think now that
I would get more good out of
that time, if I went to Berlin
or some place in Germany and
tried to perfect myself somewhat
in German. Three weeks spent
where I would have to commun-
icate in that language would
do me a great deal of good. It is
absolutely necessary that a physician
should be able to read German
about as well as English.

I do not think I would get much
good out of the month in New York.
Living is cheap in Germany and
I would really be saving money
by staying there instead of returning
to New York. I do not like the
idea of prolonging my stay away from
you, but now that I am over
here. I think it is better to get
all the advantages, I can.

I wrote to you a week ago where
to direct letters in London but
for fear that the letter may have
miscarried I will repeat it now.

c/o. Baring Brothers & Co.
8 Bishopsgate St. within
London. E.C.

Direct as above after Tuesday July 8,
for two weeks or up to July 22.
After Tuesday July 22 direct to
care of.

Perier frères et Cie.
59. Rue de Provence
Paris.

I will let you know later on
how to direct after I leave
Paris.

I have seen nothing to tell
about for the last few days.
I will go around and see
the sights during the last few
days of my stay here.
I see by this morning's paper that
there has been very hot weather
in Chicago. I hope it has
not been so bad at Pittsburgh
and that you are standing it
well and taking care of yourself.
You have not mentioned Bedford
lately. I wish you would go
down there during the hot
weather. I know it would do
you good and make you feel
stronger. You must do everything
you can to keep up your strength.

Give my love to all. I have
been intending for a long time
to write to Uncle Tom but I can
hardly find time. I will soon.

I got some of the “Rock” candy.
It is just like cream candy. It
is very good but no better than
ordinary cream candy.
